author: nisku
title: Educate  Cardano's future workforce
description: How can Cardano educate and train tomorrow's developers - young tech professionals all around the world, with a special focus on training.

assessments.note: The challenge goal needs more explanation. The main idea is clear, but some suggestion about how to do it would increase the challenge clarity. Also, the proposal would also benefit from some metrics about the current and expected size of the ecosystem, and number regarding number of tech people needed, some estimations, to give it more weight. Also, although the topic is very important, budget seems to high. It would be better to create a first challenge with smaller budget and than increase it if successful.
The bar to entering the Cardano ecosystem is still quite high. Education and bringing awareness to resources is crucial in bringing more people to Catalyst and the greater Cardano community.

Reasonable concept and valid endpoints described but proposal is very limited in its design. The author needs to provide a good deal more to this proposal to ensure that it meets the minimum requirements.
As a challenge, soliciting proposals and encouraging initiatives to train is an essential element of growing the use of Cardano protocols. An excellent use of community funds.

Developers and others are set to gain once they learn how to develop in Cardano. Once the technology becomes apparent there will be third-party efforts to support training. However, the is a need for handholding since the language (Plutus and Haskell) has comparatively low penetration among developers. A strong developer community is a major asset to any cryptocurrency.
It is important to bring more developers into the ecosystem. Educating new ones is one path.

Cardano's ecosystem is self-sustaining as can be seen by SPOs collaboration in order to strengthen the network by building tools and upgrades for their nodes. This can act as an inspiration for someone to create a hub/library of open source information for everyone to use. Eventually, an online course would be beneficial in order to encompass all of the material needed to be successful within the ecosystem. This, however, is not critical to achieve Cardano's mission in the foreseeable future.

Promoting developer education is an important aspect of Cardano's success, but the challenge is focused on DLTs and Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT, so I see no sense in defining the challenge in DLTs. I recommend removing the term as it causes unnecessary confusion and takes away the purpose of the challenge.

Skills development related to Cardano tech stack is undoubtedly important, although I think this challenge proposal is perhaps too broad and IOHK and the Foundation are already working on programmes which it might be better to see evolve before the community in Catalyst looks at how to fill in gaps or enhance.

The Catalyst community as it is today is capable of creating courses to train new people into the blockchain and Cardano ecosystems. Also, this challenge could bring new people from educational world into the Catalyst and Cardano ecosystems, and even universities: for example, the University of Zurich, that has just launched a summer course about blockchains, including Cardano, could apply for funding to create a course specifically for Cardano.

In my assessment, the current plutus pioneer program has several community members that could tackle this challenge with their specific proposals.
To come up with a industry specific and globally accepted standard will be a lot more challenging.
The proposal really lacks substance at this stage of its evolution and I cannot fully assess the feasibility without further contribution from the author.

As the Cardano Africa 360 revealed, building cardano devs at all levels will be an essential element of growth. The community already assembled has shown serious interest in marketing, education and training. I  believe this challenge would be highly subscribed with proposals.
There should be a sufficient number of people within the Ada community to be able to adress such a challenge and building projects aiming towards it.

The community has conducted much self-initiated training and another onboarding initiative. Therefore, it can come up with an innovative methodology to come up with the new ideas to provide the Cardano with enough trained workforce.
The community could definitely achieve this if funding was provided.

Catalyst and the broader Cardano community already have started equipping themselves with the tools needed to succeed today. As of right now, several winning proposals are working on creating a central source of information for all willing to challenge themselves and learn new skills.

The Catalyst community is fully capable of creating educational material to train more developers, but Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT and there is no point in establishing this restriction on the challenge theme.

The success criteria is good, to have more tech people trained in Cardano's blockchain, but the suggested key metrics are good for the long run only. It is needed to have metric for the projects development as well, for example the development of a platform, students enrolled, that can be measured within 1 year or less.

The lack of data and planning provided means that at this stage the proposal is simply an idea and as such cannot be accurately assessed in term of the success criteria and metrics to address the challenge.
Diplomas are per se not a great indicator of an educated workforce, but the sentiment is understood.
As all challenges, the verifiability of success will be the number and quality of proposals (metrics) submitted in the challenge. Not too much more to be said.
The metrics are good al in all, however they could be more detailed and diverse in order to be able to distinguish different projects and approaches within the same challenge

There is a need to improve the metrics as suggested in the proposal. Few suggestions are the (a) Formalisation of levels of the curriculum. (b) Numbers of partners for the issue of certification. (c) Evolving a methodology for funding the training. ((d) Level of diversity achieved in attracting people around the world (no of languages in which curriculum is developed etc).

The challenge needs more clear goals on how to do this. Where ar ewe aiming. Worldwide? Universities? Schools? Startup accelerators? Colleges? Build an online education course on Coursera. I realsie some of these may be the solution to the challenge, but without setting some goals of where the results should come from and what we want how do we know where to focus resources?

Given the scope and role of this challenge setting, the suggested KPI list needs to be expanded upon. The proposer is encouraged to build onto their current idea in order to present it more clearly yet with added detail.

Establishing success in 2030 precludes a reasonable measure of success. The metrics defined are subjective. When would the metrics be checked? 2030?

It is not clear what it means: "project items developed for the graduation", what would project items be?

The metric related to DLT does not make sense, as Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT.
I think a challenge proposal would need more detailed metrics and criteria for proposers and their projects to meet and submit, but those suggested are definitely a start.

importance: Educate young tech professionals in working with Cardano to ensure tomorrow's skilled workforce.
